channel.title: Question
channel.description:
i don't know if this really goes here but.. (i saw questions on the title of this section :o)
int the updating how exactly do ppl find out which class is what (what do they look for in the class that identifies it as that class)?

item.title: Question

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“1337h4x, post:20, topic:146201”][quote author=nueb35 link=topic=200173.msg1782565#msg1782565 date=1190855748]

To find their String class, just search for Constant_String “ISO-8859-1”. The method(s) where it’s referenced even contain fields “bytes” and “length”.

u forgot to tell me how to do it :
[/quote]We might as well give you the entire updater then. Learn BCEL by looking at the docs…if you get stuck or you need help just ask someone here.[/quote]

where can i find the docs ? and if there are non whats the doc cmd command? i dont remember it

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

No, MutableString extends Object. If you want to find MutableString in a deob, just look for the fields that are init to someclass.somestaticmethod(string)

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

Oh yeah I said it wrong. iirc a lot have byte[]s but only that one has a toString().

Then Class52_sub6 is the StringWrapper or whatever you want to call it in the deob (unless the deob adds to classes which I don’t know because I only used decompiled originals)

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35

ive done that and alot come out then i narrowed thosw to the 1ns that have a return or string in them and some how i got Class52_sub6

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

[quote=“nueb35, post:13, topic:146201”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=200173.msg1781527#msg1781527 date=1190793274]

Yes. Like for example, stringwrapper ALWAYS has a toString() method. If you find a class that has a toString method, then it’s probably stringwrapper. Stringwrapper has ONE byte[] which contains the string. Search the stringwrapper for a byte[] and if you find one thats the string.

(just use new String(byte[]here) to make it a string)
[/quote]Even better, MutableString is the only class with a UTF8 “hashCode” in it iirc.

u guys keep giving me method names but the names of the methods in the deob are not the same :([/quote]just search all the files for a byte[] and print out everything you find

Read full topic

(just use new String(byte[]here) to make it a string)
[/quote]Even better, MutableString is the only class with a UTF8 “hashCode” in it iirc.[/quote]

u guys keep giving me method names but the names of the methods in the deob are not the same

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

class fuckingnamer
{
byte[] b;
void fuckedupmethodhere() { … }
String toString(){ return b };
}

etc etc etc. This is just an example, don’t go out looking for “b”. Just look for a byte[] in the class.

Read full topic

so it would get byte[] b = new byte[10];
but not byte[] b;

i realy need to see an example

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

Yes. Like for example, stringwrapper ALWAYS has a toString() method. If you find a class that has a toString method, then it’s probably stringwrapper. Stringwrapper has ONE byte[] which contains the string. Search the stringwrapper for a byte[] and if you find one thats the string.

(just use new String(byte[]here) to make it a string)

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

like yakman and pwnd said, look for patterns, it really comes from the experience of playing with the client.

look at Aryan, and that has some really nice ideas in there, renamed fields, alot of the field patterns haven’t changed.

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

why dont i give you an example

theres a class which some call StringWrapper, also called MutableString, or StringWrap
it seems to be used instead of String in the client

one way to find it is to check if it has the method hashCode(), so check in every class
then, look for an instance field which is of type byte[], that is the string bytes

i think the best way to find these patterns is to play around with deobs, and find the patterns there

Read full topic
